channel.title: Nintendufo
channel.description:
So, I was discussing NES mods with bootnecklad, and came up with the idea to create a console that can play: [*]Atari 2600/5200 [*]Sega Master System [*]Sega MegaDrive/Genesis +32x [*]NES [*]SNES [*]N64
and possibly GC and Wii. Also, there would be a built in DVD/BluRay player.
I was thinking of making a button-activated mechanism to switch the control ports to the appropriate one for the console, so you dont end up having over 9000 holes in it. Also, the console won't boot up until you hit the power button, even though the console "activation" system works all the time. Was also thinking of adding a gamegenie and all that built-in, switchable of course.
The problem is: I don't have the time, skills or money to pull this off. So for now, it'll be an idea only, and perhaps, in the future, I'll be able to make it!
Also, here's a rough sketch of what it'd look like: [img]http://i30.tinypic.com/28ch8c6.png[/img]

item.title: Nintendufo
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Fat Cookies:

Can someone explain the connection between the MIPS and ARM architecture? I was wondering if an ARM cpu could run any MIPS code?

MIPS and ARM are two different architectures, like x86 and MIPS or x86 and ARM. The only way they can run each other’s code is through an emulator which is most of the time pretty slow.

Read full topic

item.title: Nintendufo
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:24, topic:293603”][quote author=peterbjornx link=topic=388486.msg2911064#msg2911064 date=1250103089]
just use a modified PC and build your own linux GUI , doesnt need to be very complicated, you wouldnt even need a window manager,
[/quote]
Uhm… if you read what I and other said, I want to be able to use the original controllers and cartridges ;)[/quote]

I’ve got all of the original controllers hooked up to my PC (NES, SNES, Sega, Atari, and PS2 I wired myself, N64 I bought an adapter for) And for the systems you are emulating here, they are all well within the realm of easily being emulated by hardware. Actually, since most of those systems ran on an ARM cpu, you could make this run on ARM as well (using linux of course) and the emulation would be made much easier and faster.

You could still support all of the cartridges, even with already-written emulators, just have a small program that dumps them to a ROM when you put them in.

Read full topic

item.title: Nintendufo
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

peterbjornx:

thats still possible, you can build a small USB box based ontop of a PIC18F microcontroller and the old snes and nes controllers use a pretty basic pinout, its just a key matrix, and about the carts, for example a GB cart uses a plain rom layout,its got the data and adress busses

This. Yeah sppt, I think your idea of using all the original hardware will make this 1. expensive 2. hard to build 3. the final product would be huge. But one problem you’d need to over come is the cartridges, you’d have to have about half a dozen ports for all the games to go in! I still think it’d be possible but it would take some time, money and labour (so far you say you haven’t got the time, tools and money, so it can stay an idea till you do!)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 04, 2009, 11:14:15 am[/size][hr]Sorry sppt, I had to design something to compete with it

I call it tehbootneckladsuperawesomehappyultraxmoparconsole

Read full topic
